text: A gentle slope. The city shimmers like a postcard below. Peaceful. Calm. SILENT. Perfect. Then- SCREECHING TIRES. Suddenly a CAR COMES CRASHING THROUGH T FRAME, a flipping blur of flying metal and BREAKING GLASS And then it’s gone. Everything’s still, just as we found
So, tell me how it works. ANGLE ON the wrecked car, CLOSE ON the eyes of MARK BRITT unconscious, hanging upside down by his Seatbelt. We can the WHEELS STILL SPINNING helplessly in the air.

I don’t know. I close my eyes. I open them. Just like you. Very slowly pull back from his eyes until we see other passengers in the car: HIS WIFE (HANNAH BRITTEN) and a TEENAGE SON (REX BRITTEN) more on them in a moment. They’re also hanging from their seatbelts, bloody and unconscious.
Let’s just start at the beginning. Suddenly, Britten’s eyes flutter open. He looks around. A takes in his wife and son hanging from their belts-
INT. DR. LEE’S OFFICE CLOSE ON Det. Mark Britten, 40ish, handsome, healed, but weight to his stare. He’d rather not remember the beginni
No. Let’s start at right now. REVEAL DR. LEE, late 30’s, Asian-American, a cerebral presence in a muted, calming, vaguely Zen environment. He makes a note in his book then looks back at Britten.
Very well. You’re back to work?

Yes.  EXT. LOWEN’S RESTAURANT/BAR - NIGHT Britten, suit and tie, steps through barricades holding b a crowd. As he does, DET. RICHARD VEGA, 30's, gregarious, the type person who talks to strangers in elevators, steps over. He’s the only one who seems excited to be at a murder sce
Detective Britten! Over here.
And they've got you working with a partner?
New guy. Vega; They just want someone to hold my hand until they know I’m okay. INT. DR. LEE’S OFFICE Lee leans on his fingers and looks at him.
And are you okay?

(long beat) Yes. EXT. LOWEN’S RESTAURANT/BAR - NIGHT There’s a cab with a shattered window, a DEAD DRIVER slum behind the wheel. Vega walks Britten through the scene like a tour guide wi slight case of nerves. He refers heavily to his notes.

So... the driver picked up a fare downtown, registered this address with dispatch. Um, he’s still got his wallet, and there’s a twenty on the seat beside him, so I think not only was it not a robbery, it looks like the fare was actually paid. Then, either the rider or someone else puts a gun to the window, BOOM, BOOM, BOOM... leaves us this messy little mystery.
Witnesses? Vega nods proudly. He’s on that. He motions to an OFFICER brings over a WITNESS, knit cap, 30’s, skinny, very polit
Okay, so I’ve interviewed about thirt Basically everybody came out of the bar when it happened. But this guy lives in the apartment building above it, saw from his window.

After I heard the shots I looked out, Saw a man in a cowboy hat run that way, up the block, and then turn into that alley. Thanks. I’ it Pet you know if I have other questions. The Officer leads the witness away. As he goes-—
Happy to help. Vega turns to Britten.
Exact same report from the bar witnesses, just_a little more chaos on the ground. Guy in a cowboy hat running away, but no one close and no one who claims to have seen the shooting.
What do we know about the driver? Back to his notes.

Right. Driver. Married. No kids. Dispatcher says he wasn’t the type to get in an argument. At this point nothing really suggests he should be dead except for the fact that he is. Britten surveys the scene. Looks past the crowds at the barricades and notices the building across the street.
Building looks like it’s got a secured front door. Let’s see if they've got a camera on it. Might have caught something we can use. Vega smiles, stares at him a beat.
What?
I just, um... want to thank you.
For what?

I got passed over for detective three times before this assignment. I’m pretty sure I only got the boost because you requested me. I just wanted you to know I, uh... I won't disappoint you. Britten’s starts away.
I didn’t request anyone. If you got promoted it’s because they didn’t want to waste anyone else’s time baby-sitting me. As Vega takes that in-
And then what?

I go home. INT. BRITTEN’S HOUSE - NIGHT It’s a modest but homey craftsman bungalow that looks a million miles from murder investigations. As Britten steps in, his wife, HANNAH, the woman from the wreck, late 30’s, stunning, warm, looks down from a ladde where she’s repainting a wall. She smiles.
Perfect. Just in time to help me clean up. He looks at the dropcloth, brushes, paint.
Maybe it’s time to just embrace the mess. INT. DR. LEE’S OFFICE Lee is making notes.
Did she start redoing the house after the accident?
After the funeral.
(nodding) That’s a common reaction. We all look for ways to start fresh. Has she gotten to your son’s room?
Britten opens the room. Typical teenage chaos with an odd sense of being frozen in amber. He stares at it.

No. I’m not sure she’s even been in it yet. INT. BRITTEN’S HOUSE - MARK'S BEDROOM - NIGHT Britten crawls into bed next to Hannah, who’s asleep. He gives her a kiss on the cheek, lays back, closes his eyes CLOSE ON HIS EYES as we hear DR. STEPHANIE EVANS.
And then?
INT. BRITTEN’S HOUSE - MARK’S BEDROOM - MORNING Britten opens his eyes.

I wake up. He looks beside him. His wife isn’t there. He looks down his wrist. There’s a GREEN rubber band around it. DR. EVANS ee What’s the purpose of the rubber bands? ; BRITTEN (V.O. Sometimes it gets confusing. They just help me keep things straight. INT. BRITTEN’S HOUSE - HALLWAY - MORNING Britten pulls on his coat as he steps into the hall. Then, post as he passes his SON’S DOOR, IT SUDDENLY OPENS into the hall comes REX BRITTEN, the other passenger from wreck, 15, tall, good looking, and only moderately awake. Britten doesn’t seem at all surprised to see him.

Morning. Rex simply emits a half awake GRUMBLE. INT. BRITTEN’S HOUSE - KITCHEN - MORNING Britten and Rex eat cereal, watch Sportscenter. Not a lot chatter, but Britten seems unsure how to change that. A car outside HONKS. Rex jumps up, grabs a large TENNIS B stuffs in an extra racquet.
That’s Aaron. I gotta go.
What about the uh... the match. Rex stops.
What about it?
Do you want me there? Rex shrugs.
Whatever you think. He starts out.

Wait. Britten stands, walks over, hugs the boy. Rex more endure than reciprocates. Britten doesn’t care. He just holds on INT. DR. EVANS’ OFFICE - DAY REVEAL DR. STEPHANIE EVANS, late 20’s, attractive, with a the eagerness of someone new enough to her job to still l it. Her office is modern but not stark. She takes no notes. Instead, she tends to smile and tilt head as she listens, as if every answer is right.
And you said the tennis is new?
Sort of. His mom was very good. Played in college. She taught him. He used to play until he discovered football.
But he’s decided to take it up again. Since the funeral. Britten nods. DR. EVANS (CONT’D) (smiling) Great. What else?

Britten steps into a MURDER SCENE. Two bodies, TOM and IR BAKER are laid out, stabbed, blood everywhere. Vega walks toward Britten, but then simply nods curtly an WALKS BY AS IF THEY BARELY KNOW EACH OTHER. Instead we hear the voice of DET. ISAIAH FREEMAN (‘BIRD’)

You see this coffee maker? Britten turns to see BIRD, African-American, 50’s, salt a epper hair and an air of having seen it all, twice. He indicates a complicated coffee maker on the counter. BIRD (CONT’D) My ex always wanted one of these. Told her she wanted a six hundred dollar coffee maker she should not have married a police. (beat) We eventually agreed on that. (re: the scene) Tell me what you see, I’1ll tell you what you miss. Britten surveys the mess.
Husband and wife victims? Bird is playing with the coffee machine, but nods. BRITTEN (CONT’D) Multiple stab wounds, Some signs that they put up a fight.
Also some signs that they lost.
No wallet or purse?
Gone, along with one of the cars.
So what, just a home invasion that turned messy? Bird stares at the coffee maker.

Why I’ve avoided success at all costs. Work your whole life to get some nice stuff just so someone can kill you for it. Britten looks around, notices pictures on the walls. Many show a YOUNG GIRL with the couple. Bird picks up on this.

No sign of the little girl. Checking with friends, family, hoping someone tells us she wasn’t ome. INT. BAKER HOUSE - GIRL’S BEDROOM Britten walks into a nexus of Twilight posters and the co pink. Begins to poke around. Bird waits in the doorway. Britten opens the closet, stops.
You smell that?
I’ve been nursing a cold since the Carter administration. Britten leans into the closet, kneels, pokes his head int the corner. SNIFFS. When he comes out-
Girl was here when it happened.
How do you know?
Because she hid in the closet and pissed her pants. Either she ran when the killer left or he-
What I get for hoping. Bird turns, shouts to the officers in the other room-— BIRD (CONT’D) Boys! New deal! As Bird starts to give orders, Britten looks back at the closet. OFF his expression -
And this has been happening since the accident? INT. DR. EVANS’ OFFICE Britten looks at her.
Yes.

Fascinating. (reigning it in) Not to be insensitive, it’s just... our brain’s main function is to protect us. Sometimes that means sensing danger or feeling pain. And sometimes it actually means deceiving ourselves. (to explain) The {38s OF a loved one is one of the most emotionally crippling things we face. We come up with all sorts of ways to get through it. Like your son taking up his mother’s sport to maintain some sense of connection with her. But your brain... it’s created an entire reality where i¥ou haven't actually lost your wife at all. INT. DR. LEE’S OFFICE Dr. Lee is in the middle of a similar thought.

An elaborate and ongoing dream in which you haven’t lost your son, relieving you of the ob igation of dealing with his death. I’m not sure I’ve ever seen a coping mechanism quite like it. Britten looks at him. A beat.
How do you know it’s a dream?
I'm sorry?

How do you know that the world where my wife died and my son lived is my dream? Maybe that’s reality, and this world, where my wife lived and my son died, is the dream.  10. INT. DR. EVANS’ OFFICE Dr. Evans looks genuinely surprised.
Wait. You mean you can’t tell them apart? Britten shakes his head. She’s practically giddy. DR. EVANS (CONT’D) Incredible. INT. DR. LEE’S OFFICE Lee looks incredulous.
oxen re saying you’re not eon ident whether you’re asleep or awake at this very moment? Britten looks at the rubber band on his arm. It’s BLUE.

Everything feels just as real in one world as it does in the other. I never look down and discover I’m naked, or late for a test. Never suddenly start to fly. Whether I’m with my wife or my son, everything is completely normal. Then I close my eyes, open them, and the other one 1s waiting. A long beat. Dr. Lee makes a note.
Well, I can assure you, Detective Britten, this is not a dream. Britten can’t help but smile.
What?
That’s exactly what the other psychiatrist Said.
Britten and Vega are scanning through the security camera footage. As a cab rolls into frame-
Whoa. Right there. They let it play.

Could hardly ask for a better angle. A SKINNY MAN IN A COWBOY HAT opens the rear door, hands a twenty to the driver, then gets out. He takes a step and then turns and FIRES THREE SHOTS thro the window, ling the driver. Then he looks DIRECTLY AT THE CAMERA, and TIPS HIS HAT be running away. Vega and Britten look at each other, surpri
Wow. Part murder, part performance piece. Britten rewinds, watches the shooting again, then the pol hat tip. The killer’s hat is low, his sunglasses large.
Disguise doesn’t give us_a lot to go on. Let’s pull’a still and put it out to all the local- Suddenly an OFFICER anxiously sticks his head in.
Detectives? We’ve got another one.
Another what?
Dead cabbie. OFF Britten and Vega exchanging a look-

Britten and Vega step through the large crowds to find a driven up on the curb and into a pole outside a bustling outdoor shopping mall, driver slumped behind the wheel. As they take it in, an OFFICER steps up, gestures.  12.

Cab pulls up. Door opens. Three loud bangs. Everyone scatters, the driver manages to run up on the sidewalk until he smacks into this pole. He turns back to the crowds of people. OFFICER (CONT’ ») Everyone reports seeing an overweight man, heav eard, glasses, some kind of ball cap, walking away from the scene. Heads straight into the crowd and then... disappears. Bird steps up.
No heros today boys, just a hundred something witnesses who can’t wait to tell you their story. Over and over and over. He tears some sheets out of his notebook, hands them to Britten with a smile.
Still happy you came back? As Bird goes Britten stares at him. It’s weird, switching partners. Vega doesn’t seem sorry to see Bird go.
(muttering) Burnout. Off Britten’s look-
Sorry. Just... I work my ass off to get the same job he sleepwalks through.

Maybe he just knows where to spend his energy. Britten turns back to the cab, follows a line of sight to top of a pole across the way. On top- a camera. BRITTEN (CONT'D) . Wanna take a guess what we’re going to see?

Britten, Vega, and a MALL SECURITY OFFICER are gathered around the small bank of monitors. They focus on one as-  13. A cab pulls up. The door opens. AN OVERWEIGHT MAN IN A TRUCKER HAT starts to get out, and as he does, fires thre shots through the backseat. The cab lurches forward. As people panic, the overweight looks right at the camera, DOFFS HIS CAP, and then walks Britten freezes the tape on the suspect, the face disguis behind the beard and coke bottle glasses, almost useless.
I’1l take this back to the lab, see if they can enhance it.
What should I do?
Didn't Bird say something about a hundred witnesses to interview? OFF Vega’s fading expression- INT. DR. LEE’S OFFICE - DAY Dr. Lee looks up from his notes.
What does your wife say about your condition?
(beat) We don’t talk about it.
INT. BRITTEN’S HOUSE - KITCHEN - FLASHBACK Britten is talking while Hannah prepares dinner.

At first I told her everything. That he’d given up football and gone back to tennis. About the girl e was getting calls from. Suddenly Hannah just bursts into tears. BRITTEN (V.O.) (CONT’D) But it’s not the same for her. To her he’s not still alive, it’s just some dream I keep having. And hearing about it isn’t comforting, it’s... torture.  14. INT. DR. LEE’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Britten looks at Lee.
I actually wasn’t looking to come back to work. She sort of forced my hand.
She wanted you to get back to a routine?

No. She wanted to break all our routines. She wanted to move. Like cross the country and start over. She says it’s hard to live with that empty room upstairs. My best argument for staying was that the seniority and benefits I'd worked for wouldn’t follow us.
But you don’t really care about those things? You just wanted to remain where you are.
For me, the room upstairs isn’t empty. Lee notes this.

Detective, I’m going to be frank. For you to process what’s happened, heal, and move on, it’s imperative that you, acknowledge what’s real and what’s fantasy. We can talk about your dreams, but we have to accept them as just that, dreams. Do you understand? Britten eventually nods.
Let’s talk about your partners. Why do you think they’re different between your dream and reality?
Britten and Vega interview a witness. Vega smiles broadly Britten makes notes.  15.
I don’t know. I never worked with a partner before the accident.
Britten and Bird are looking over bloody crime scene phot pointing out various items, making notes.
They told me they dante me with someone for while and... I don’t know, I got one in one world and the other in the other. INT. DR. EVANS’ OFFICE Dr. Evans is nodding adamantly.
But you said that they don’t like each other, this Bird and Vega?
Vega’s just new. Still thinks we fix things. Bird knows better.

It makes perfect sense. Your brain doesn’t want you to know which world is real and which isn’t. It would defeat the purpose of the coping mechanism. If you had the same partner, you mig t invent details about them in your dream that were disproved in reality and you'd suddenly know which was which. This way, you’re free to create a story for each of them, and their animosity helps keep them from crossing paths and forcing you to reconcile what you’ ve imagine with the truth. It’s the same reason you've given yourself different therapists. INT. DR. LEE’S OFFICE Dr. Lee closes his notebook.
It’s these little details and differences we should focus on.
Britten and Vega step out of the interview room, call the next witness in. As they wait Britten looks across the department at BIRD, NOSE IN A BOOK AT HIS DESK, oblivious
Why?
EXT. RESIDENTIAL STREET —- AFTERNOON Britten and Bird stand outside of a house. There’s a CAR the street surrounded by OFFICERS and TECHS.
Because dreams aren’t meant to be sustained. When we pull at the threads they tend to fall apart. As Britten watches, VEGA GETS INTO A CAR DOWN THE BLOCK.

Your partners are threads. And once we start to pull on them, I think we can help you see the truth. Vega shoots Britten a brief glimpse from the car, then dr away. Britten stares after him. The sound of Bird KNOCKING on the house’s door snaps Brit back to the task at hand. An UPPER MIDDLE CLASS HOUSEWIFE opens the door.

Ma‘am. Detectives Freeman and Britten. We’re working the Baker homicides down the street. (beat) We're told you noted this car in the area yesterday? He indicates the car crawling with officers and techs.
Yes. We’re all pretty close on the street. You kin8 of have a sense of what people drive. It just didn’t look like it... fit
Did you see anyone in or around the car?
No. Is it involved in the case?  17.
It’s a_ stolen vehicle. It’s ossible the suspect used it to get into the area and then left it.
When did you notice the vehicle?
(thinking) I guess... around five. This raises eyebrows.
Are you sure?
Yes. My husband had just texted me he was on his way home. I could check the text for the exact time if you want.
Why don’t you do that. As she disappears the detectives eye one another, thinkin
The father made a call from inside the house at 5:30.
Mom's car was confirmed home by 6.

And time of death was around 9. So that means we’ve got the suspect in the area for almost four hours with both of his victims home before he actually strikes. (beat ) When did the girl get dropped off? Bird's already thinking the same thing.
Close to 8:45. Everything clicks in a way Britten was hoping it wouldn’t
If he post wanted to rob a couple of rich people he had all the time in the world. He didn’t want money. (looking at Bird) He was after the girl all along.
Britten and Bird address other officers as papers are pas

This wasn’t random. He knew who he was after, and he waited for her, which means he had to have come into contact with her before the night of the murders. These are all the registered sex offenders whose homes or work might have put them in contact with our missing girl. There’s a lot here so we’re going to divide them up for the first sweep. If you get someone you can’t immediately eliminate, let’ Bird or myself know and we’ll get into them personally. Everyone breaks up, begins to head out. Bird starts to go looks back to see Britten standing, staring at his watch.
You coming? Britten hesitates. Then-
I’ve got something I’ve got to do.
Now? Britten thinks about that. Wavers. Then-
Just take the first couple. I only need an hour or two.
For what? As Britten starts to go -
I told someone I’d be somewhere. Bird, annoyed and confused, watches him leave.

Britten sits in the bleachers. It’s not a packed house, b there’s a fair number of people for a tennis match. On the court Rex tosses up a ball and whips a blistering serve right past his opponent. Britten smiles, CLAPS.  19. Suddenly, Rex’s COACH (TARA) slides in next to Britten.

After two years playing football I didnt expect him to end up in the inal. Britten looks over at her. 30’s, long, slender, like some who not only plays a sport for a living, but does it well She extends her hand.
Tara. I’m the coach.
(shakes her hand) Right. As Rex wins another point-
He’s exceptionally talented. Britten CLAPS, keeps his eyes on Rex.
He had a very good teacher.
(genuine) I’m so sorry. She was an amazing person. Britten looks at her, nods. TARA (gONr’D) You know, we used to play doubles together. She could have played professionally.
You think so?
I did, and she was always better than me. I think the grind just didn't appeal to her.
But it appealed to you?
Thought it would be more winning Wimbledon and less qualifying in New Jersey. Britten smiles. A beat.
I’m not sure what he’s doing out there to be honest. (MORE )
I know it’s been hard on him, but he doesn’t really tell me much. His mom was the one he talked to.
We've talked about it a little.
(surprised, a little hurt) Really?
(easing the blow) Sometimes it’s just easier for boys to talk to a woman about that kin of stuff.

I’ve tried. I just... my job makes it hard to be around. And the work is like learning another language. At some point I think I forgot how to have conversations that weren’t evidence, suspect, motive. (beat What... what’s he say?
Nothing you don’t know. He misses her a lot. This helps him miss her a little less. Rex wins another point. They both CLAP.

Match point. If he wins this easily after a long layoff I may never get him to practice. Rex throws the ball up and absolutely HAMMERS it over the net. The other player doesn’t even move. Game, set, match Britten, Tara, and the other spectators CLAP and CHEER. B REX JUST STANDS THERE, staring over the net. Then- He simply falls to his knees and begins CRYING. Not victo tears. Kid who’s lost his mom tears. Britten and Tara rush to him. But as they get close, it’s TARA THAT REX GRABS FOR. He wraps himself around her and CRIES into her shoulder. Britten stands watching, helpless.
Britten, Rex, and Tara sit at a table in the largely dese bar area. Each has a soda, some picked at fries between t  21. Rex is recovered, but the conversation is mostly two way Britten spectating.
No way. I watch total garbage TV and I don’t even watch that.
Come on. It’s about models.
I think that holds a different appeal for a 15 year old boy than it does for me. Rex smiles, which Britten sort of marvels at. Tara seems notice Britten on the outside looking in.
What about you, Mark? You have a favorite show?
(trying) Um... I don’t know. I like that one with the deranged chef.
(surprised) Really? I always thought mom recorded that.
Nope That’s mine. (beat) Why? You like it?
(shrugs ) It’s okay. (long beat) Did you see the one where he made that guy eat the- Suddenly, Britten’s cell RINGS. Rex stops mid sentence.
I’m sorry. I just-
(flat) It’s fine.
(answering) Britten.
(filter) Bird. We found the Bakers’ car. Waverly Long Term Parking lot by the airport. (MORE )
We may have just missed him. How quick can you get here?
Um... He looks at Rex who can already read his mind.
You have to go. Britten dies a little at his son’s words. Then-
(into phone I’ve gotta get Rex home and I’1l be right there. As he hangs up-
I can take him if you want. REX . . Yeah. I’1l get a ride with Tara. It’s clearly not about convenience, it’s what Rex wants.

Uh. Yeah. Okay. I’1ll, um, I’1l see you in a bit then. Rex gest nods. Britten doesn’t know what else to do. He h for the door, disappointed with how that went. He almost gets there when Rex jogs up behind him.
Dad? Britten turns. A beat as Rex seems unsure what to say.
Um... I’m glad you came today.
Me too. A beat. REX HUGS HIM. The look on Britten’s face says the gesture means everything to him. They break. A long beat. BRITTEN (CONT’D) Your idea or Tara’s? Rex smiles. His dad’s not stupid.
She's good at this kind of stuff.  23.
(smiles) I won't be late. Promise. As Rex goes, Britten catches Tara’s eye. He mouths ‘thank She smiles, nods.

It’s drizzling. Bird is standing under an umbrella by a B as TECHS crawl around it taking pictures. Britten reaches him, looks inside the car, dried blood al over the seats. Bird motions to the passenger side, point out blood on the ground.
When they got spe here they said that was stil resh He hands Britten some photos of the same scene, but from earlier, when the daylight was just fading. He points to blood trail.
Drizzle makes it hard to say, but they think we missed him by less than 45 minutes. Britten looks around. They’re at the edge of a large and intermittently populated parking lot.
I don’t suppose anyone saw anything.
Nope. And no cameras, But the stolen car we found in the neighborhood was taken less than a mile from here.

So_he drives his car to this lot, walks off and steals one to get to the girl’s house. Kills her parents, abducts her, and then comes back here and ditches the family BMW for his vehicle. (walking along the car) If you're going . to move a kidnapping victim from one car to another, you probably don’t park far away. He looks at the number on the parking space that the BMW in. 589. He looks at the space right next to it. 590.  24. BRITTEN (CONT’D) So we need someone who can tell us about the car parked in space 590 for_the last day and_a half. Let’s pull the plates on all these cars, see if anyone remembers it. Bird nods. Britten eyes the photos again. Notices somethi
We should also try to figure out who was in this space directly behind 590. 611. Ih BIRD Why? Britten shows him the photo.

It’s got a dry spot that the rain hadn't covered about the same size as the one in 590. So they probably left around the same time. If anyone's going to have seen anything or remember what was in space | 590 it’s probably whoever was in tres blood on the ground) We find any of the girl’s blood in the house?
Just the parents.
Well, if this was fresh it certainly ¢ didn’t belong to them. So either she’s somehow gotten our killer bleeding- They share a look.
Or we don’t have a lot of time.
Britten works the phones. Photos of license plates surrou him as well as a drawing on his wall with the space 589, and 611, right behind 590, all circled.
Right - I’m calling about _a car you t parked at the Waverly Long erm Parking Lot. Yes.
We see him crossing license plates off a list.  25. We see his eyes glazing over as he struggles to stay awak We see him sipping a cup of coffee. Bird steps over.
Anything?
(shakes his head) You?
Nope. Apparentl eople don’t memorize all ‘the Rearby cars when they park. Britten looks at his watch.
Dammit. It’s almost two. I told him I wouldn’t do this. As Britten starts to gather his things-—
Your boy. How’s he... handling things?
(shrugs ) I don’t know. I can read you better than him. But then I’ve probably Spent more time in the department an at home over the last fifteen years.

Birthdays, anniversaries, graduations. You name it, I’ve missed it. Used to feel bad about but... what we see, people stabbed to death, kids taken... it’s toxic waste. Work in it, you end y radioactive. So for every thin I've missed, there’re ten I ruined because I came home with dead people on my mind. Job’s not just about catching bad guys. It’s about making sure the people you love don’t see just how ugly it really is out there. (beat) Sometimes staying at your desk doesn’t mean you’re neglecting anyone. It just means you don’t want them to see what’sS on it. Bird pats the bloody crime scene photos, walks off.  26. INT. BRITTEN’S CAR - LATE NIGHT Britten drives, Bird’s words ringing in his ears. The han the wheel has a GREEN rubber band around the wrist.

BRITTEN’S CAR - MORNING Britten’s hand on the wheel, but now with a BLUE rubber b He fights the morning traffic as he heads for the station As he sits at a light, a YELLOW CAB pulls up beside him. looks over as the ight changes. Britten starts his turn into the station, then notices th cab pulling to a stop right in front. He pauses mid turn. A BLONDE WOMAN IN A BLACK DRESS AND WIDE HAT gets out. As people SCREAM and start to run, the woman looks up at station and TIPS HER HAT. Britten jams on the accelerator and TEARS OUT, barreling the sidewalk towards the cab. The Woman bolts. As Britten dodges pedestrians, the woman races into _an alleyw yway between the station and the la office building next door. When Britten’s way is blocked, he abandons the car and le out only to find OFFICERS sprinting towards him, guns dra
Britten slows up, reaches into his pocket.
Britten stops, slowly draws his badge, keeps his tone eve
Detective Britten. I’m just getting my badge. The officer holds his bead as Britten produces his badge. beat, then, satisfied, they take off towards the alley.  27.
